context: For foule usure° and lucre of vilanie,°
Our blisful lady, Cristes moder dere
That in an aley° hadde a privee place;
O cursed folk of Herodes al newe
Biforn this lamb, and singe a song al newe
And, for the worship of his moder dere
This welle° of mercy, Cristes moder° swete
Enclosen they his litel body swete;
That fresshe floures, blewe, and white, and rede
That fresshe floures, blewe, and white, and rede
Ben quike again, that winter dede made
Ben quike again, that winter dede made
“Now uncle dere,” quod she, “tel it us
Of grete estat, that ever I saw my live;
Sith yow is tid thus faire an aventure?”
Lat be to me your fremde maner speche
And seide, “Gladly, leve nece dere
And seide, “Gladly, leve nece dere
And though my tale as now be to yow newe
Yet trist alwey, ye shal me finde trewe;
The goode, wise, worthy, fresshe, and free
The goode, wise, worthy, fresshe, and free
“Allas! he which that is my lord so dere
That is so trewe and worthy, as ye see
“No, wis,” quod he, “min owene nece dere.”
“Ye, doutelees,” quod she, “min uncle dere.”
This other day, nought gon ful longe while
Ledest the fin, by juste purveiaunce
That men hem wrien with asshen pale and dede.’
“O mercy, dere nece,” anoon quod he
Now beth nought wrooth, my blood, my nece dere.”
“And eek I knowe, of longe time agoon
That he may make avaunt, by juste cause;
Our wreche is this, our owene wo to drinke.
Nothing ne acheveth, be him looth or dere.”
And othere of hir wommen, a grete route
Ben humble subgit, trewe in min entente
“What, is the sonne wers, of kinde righte
Reherce it nedeth nought, for ye ben wise.
This Troilus, and seide, “O Venus dere
In grete disese abideth for the peine.”
Were his nailes pointed never so sharpe
“Now, goode nece, be it never so lite
Now for the love of me, my nece dere
So were his dayes sory outher gladde.
And seide, “Lord, and freend, and brother dere
Which hadde his lord and grete freend ben ay;
Quod Pandarus, “If ye, my lord so dere
But, for the love of God, min uncle dere
If that I may, and alle folk be trewe.”
Now faire brother, beth al hool, I preie!”
Deiphebus, and my suster leef and dere
Quod tho Criseyde, “Go we, uncle dere”;
Hir freendes soules, as wel olde as yonge
Hir freendes soules, as wel olde as yonge
A dagon° of your blanket,° leve° dame
Our suster dere, lo! here I write your name;
¶“Pees,” quod our Host, “for Cristes moder dere;
But of your grete goodness, by your leve
Suffisen° us, though they be nat ful gode.
‘Blessed be they that povre° in spirit been.’
But we that humble been and chast and pore
Of charitable and chaste bisy freres
And for to builden Cristes owne chirche.
I coude of ire sey so muche sorwe
But if° it be unto a poure man.
To a poure man men sholde hise vices telle
¶“Now Thomas, leve brother, lef° thin ire;°
That in this world is noon so poure° a page,°
O nice° proude cherl, I shrewe° his face!
Lo, sires,” quod the lord, “with harde grace,°
And Jankin hath ywonne a newe goune.—
Yet for as muche as ye, my lord so dere
And tak a wif, for hye Goddes sake;
“Ye wol,” quod he, “min owene peple dere
But nathelees I see your trewe entente
In which that povre folk of that village
Amonges thise povre folk ther dwelte a man
Hir olde povre fader fostred she;°
And made hir bed ful harde and nothing softe;
I wol no thing; ye be my lord so dere;
And tentifly° she kepte hir fader dere.
And sette hir ful of nowches° grete and smale;
To every wight° she woxen is° so dere
That men and wommen, as wel yonge as olde
That men and wommen, as wel yonge as olde
Were wrothe,° she wold bringen hem atoon;°
So° wise and ripe° wordes hadde she
Nat longe time after that this Grisild
That I yow took out of your povre array
That I yow took in povre estaat ful lowe
And though to me that ye be lief° and dere
Your owene thing;° werketh after your wille.
“Have heer again your litel yonge maide.°
And him presenteth with his doghter dere.
Ye been our lord, doth with your owne thing
The more trewe, if that it were possible
For° he a povre womman wedded hadde
And am your trewe wif, it is no drede
And of your newe wif, God of his grace
But sooth is seid, algate I finde it trewe—
Love is noght old as whan that it is newe.
Remembre yow, min owne lord so dere
For out of doute this olde povre man
As womman can, ne can ben half so trewe
Was couth° eek, that a newe markisesse
Deliting ever in rumbel° that is newe
Ay ful of clapping,° dere ynogh a jane;°
Thus seiden sadde folk° in that citee
To han a newe lady of hir toun.
That in so povre array was for to see
As coude a povre° fostred creature.”
Now knowe I, dere wif, thy stedfastnesse,”
I wol with lusty° herte fresshe and grene
Sin° ye be stronge as is a greet camaille;°
To make lithe° of that° was harde.
And queinte° maner of figures
Of olde werke, then I saw ever.
In Itaile, with ful moche pine,°
Renne and crie, as thou were woode,°
Venus, how ye, my lady dere
Allas! is every man thus trewe,°
And deide through the wounde smerte.°
¶Now faire blisfull, O Cipris,°
Of Loves folk, if they be glade
Of olde forleten° aqueintaunces;
And stant eek in so juste° a place
Loud or privee, foul or faire
His winges malt,° and he fel wete
Moche is thy might and thy noblesse!”
“And why?” “For I am now to olde.”
Or Ariones harpe fine,°
That never herde I thing so hie
To bilden on a place hie;
Of olde time, and yit they were

Ther saugh I famous, olde and yonge

That bore hath up a longe while

“What?” quod she, “and be ye wode?°
They seiden: “Mercy, lady dere!
Hit shal don us as moche gode
At regard° of our grete ese.
Worthy, wise, and gode also
Worthy, wise, and gode also
And seiden: “Lady, lefe° and dere
And seiden: “Lady, lefe° and dere
As gode folk han in goodnes;
And fulle of vice and wikked thewes;°
As gode folk han for goodnesse;
Sufficeth me, as I were dede
Was made of twigges, falwe,° rede
A newe tiding prevely
As dooth the faire, white mone
I herde a grete noise withalle
Adorneth al the thridde hevene faire!
O sonnes leef, O Joves doughter dere
Ye do hem corteis be, fresshe and benigne
Thus wole I pleine unto my lady dere;
“Ye, swete herte? allas, I may nought rise
Now pale, unto Criseyde, his lady dere
Was, twyes, “Mercy, mercy, swete herte!”
“What that I mene, O swete herte dere?”
Quod Troilus, “O goodly fresshe free!
And I to ben your verray humble trewe
Lo, this mene I, min owene swete herte.”
“Min alderlevest Lord, and brother dere
But gode brother, do now as thee oughte
May thenken that she is my nece dere
For which these wise clerkes that ben dede
Han ever yet proverbed to us yonge
For wel wot I, in wise folk, that vice
“But now to purpos; leve brother dere
“But now to purpos; leve brother dere
For at thy day thou shalt me trewe finde.
That han in winter dede been and dreie
Be she never so faire or wel yshape
In al this while, unto his lady dere;
As I have told, and in this time swete
“But goode nece, if I mighte ever plese
Criseyde, whiche that coude as muche good
“I wol,” quod she, “min uncle leef and dere
And him hir ‘leef ’ and ‘dere herte’ calle
Ye knowe eek how it is your owne knight
And Troilus hir knight to hir so dere
Is on yow two, and ye ben bothe wise
“That is wel seid,” quod he, “my nece dere
Now doth him sitte, gode nece dere
Now doth him sitte, gode nece dere
Your grete trouthe, and servise every day
Ben to yow trewe and hool, with al min herte;
Have mercy, swete herte min, Criseyde!
Foryeve it me, min owene swete herte.”
Ful bittre drink; and for to han gladnesse
As she that juste cause hadde him to triste
Was Troilus, and hath his lady swete;
Hir sides longe, fleshly, smothe, and white
Min herte swete, how I yow mighte plese!
That am unworthy to so swete a wight.
And for the love of God, my lady dere
For certes, fresshe wommanliche wif
My ground of ese, and al min herte dere
Awey, thou foule daunger and thou fere
Ye humble nettes of my lady dere!
For wo, or elles whan that folk ben sike
Servise of love, hadde eres also longe
And therto dronken hadde as hoot and stronge
And fallen in a newe joye anoon
But lest this night, that was to hem so dere
With herte sore, to Troilus thus seide:—
Gan therwithal Criseyde his lady dere
And with a sik she seide, “O herte dere
Beth to me trewe, or elles were it routhe;
That al my drede is that ye, nece swete
And seide, “Freend, as I am trewe knight
I hadde it never half so hote as now;
But now I fele a newe qualitee
The bountee of his righte lady dere
Icomen was the blisful time swete
Love, that his hestes hath in heven hie
On hertes sore, and kepe hem that ben trewe.”
Is with Criseyde, his owne herte swete.

¶This cave was also as derke
For certes, swete, I am but dede;
Me met° so inly° swete a swevene,°
Was never herd so swete a steven,°
Was nowher herd yet half so swete
With many gladde° gilde° stremes;
And eek the welken° was so faire
Blew, bright, clere was the aire
Fro al the hounds a prive° way.
Ful thikke of gras, ful softe and swete
With floures fel,° faire under fete
And his spirites wexen dede;°
Doun to his hert, to make him warme—
Him thought his sorwes were so smerte°
Were for his sorwes never so wrothe.°
He saide, “I prey thee, be not wrothe
That semeth ful seke° under your side.”
“Graunt mercy, goode frend,” quod he
My lif, my lustes° be me loothe
For al welfare and I be wroothe.°
Alway deyinge, and be not dede
That is a false flatering beste;
That is ay fals, and semeth wele
I hold that wish nat worthe a stre!°
Was false whiche° a fool she was!
To love hooly with goode entente
And worship° to my lady dere.
¶“And this was longe, and many a yere
As a white walle or a table;
Al° were to me yliche° goode
That as the sommers sonne brighte

Debonair, goode, glade, and sadde,°
Debonair, goode, glade, and sadde,°
Simple, of good mochel,° noght to wide;

¶“And goode faire White she hete,°

I was right yonge, soth to say

Noght longe time, leve° hit wel.
My lady, that is so faire and bright!”—
I am adred she wol be wrothe;
So moche beaute, trewely
I most have tolde hir or be dede.
Ful ofte I wex both pale and rede;°
That she wold be my lady swete;
Ever to be stedfast and trewe
For evermore, min herte swete!
¶“Therwith she was alway so trewe,°
Our joy was ever yliche newe;°
Ylich they were both glad and wrothe;°

Lord, he was glad, and seide, “Freend so dere
Be diligent, and trewe, and ay wel hide.
For this have I herd seide of wise ylered
Dede were his japes and his crueltee
He putte it in our owne jugement.
So that the clerkes° be nat with me wrothe
As three of hem were goode and two were badde.
That ech of hem ful blisful was and fawe°
I sey nat this by wives that ben wise

¶“ ‘Sir olde kainard,° is this thin array?
Sir olde lechour, lat thy japes° be!
To wedde a povre womman, for costage;°
Til they be wedded; olde dotard shrewe!
And clep° me “faire dame” in every place;
For certein, olde dotard, by your leve,°
Ful giltelees, by Goddes swete pine!°
¶“Than wolde I seye, ‘Goode lief,° taak keep°
And han a sweete spiced° conscience
But I wol kepe it for your owne tooth.°
Whan I had dronke a draughte of sweete win.

The lettres eek, that she of olde time
And seide, “Leve brother Pandarus
And to Pandare, his owene brother dere
So pitously and with so dede an hewe
Me caughte first my righte lady dere.
‘Now goode swete, love me wel, I preye.’
Herde I min alderlevest lady dere
With softe vois he, of his lady dere
I shal be glad, if al the world be trewe!
Whan hennes rood my righte lady dere
For wise folk in bokes it expresse
Yong, fresshe, strong, and hardy as lioun;
Trewe as steel in ech condicioun;
This Diomede, as fresshe as braunche in May
And after this, withouten longe lette
“What wene ye your wise fader wolde
“What wol ye more, lufsom lady dere?
Inwith hir fadres faire brighte tente.
That she him yaf the faire baye stede
To Diomede algate I wol be trewe.
Almost, ywis, al newe was my care.
Er that the mone, O dere herte swete!
So were his throwes sharpe and wonder stronge.
Which that men clepeth wode Jalousie
Priam ful ofte, and eek his moder dere
The blisful goddes, through hir grete might
What newe lust, what beaute, what science
What wratthe of juste cause have ye to me?
I fele now so sharpe a newe peine
I fele now so sharpe a newe peine
And to Criseyde, his owene lady dere
As ye wel knowe how longe time agoon
“For which to yow, with dredful herte trewe
And over al this, that ye, my lady dere
Foryeve it me, min owene swete herte.
As wisly as in al I am yow trewe.
“Ywis, min owene dere herte trewe
“Ywis, min owene dere herte trewe
And fareth wel, goodly faire fresshe may
And fareth wel, goodly faire fresshe may
She gan first smile, and seide, “O brother dere
Be war by thise ensamples trewe and olde.
With Goddes owene finger wroght° was he
O noble almighty Sampson, leef° and dere
And bar° the heven on his nekke longe.
To which image bothe yonge and olde
For ech of hem hadde other° leef° and dere.
And for the Grekes weren me so leve
Ben with the folk of Troye alwey so wrothe
O Juvenal, Lord! trewe is thy sentence
To reve a wight that most is to him dere
As wisly were it fals as it is trewe
Forthi be glad, min owene dere brother
Ech for his vertu holden is for dere
And upon newe cas lith newe avis.
And upon newe cas lith newe avis.
It lith not in my power, leve brother.
But now thy cominge is to me so swete
And seide, “Parde, leve brother dere
Shulle in a strete as dogges liggen dede
Er thou be war; and shortly, brother dere
Fro man to man, and made this tale al newe
She rente, and eek hir fingres longe and smale
Shul blake been, in tokening, herte swete
Shul blake been, in tokening, herte swete
And, for the love of God, my nece dere
And nought encresse, leve nece swete;
And nought encresse, leve nece swete;
Wommen ben wise in short avisement;
That in thin heed thin eyen semen dede?
As bittre weren, out of teres kinde
And thou, Criseyde, o swete herte dere
This al and som, my dere herte swete.
That day by day, min owene herte dere
“For if that it be pees, min herte dere
And that hir herte trewe was and kinde
And was in purpos ever to be trewe;
That of hir heste he might hir trewe finde.
Dwel rather here, min owene swete herte!
“For trewely, min owene lady dere
“For which, with humble, trewe, and pitous herte
Til into time that we shul ben dede;
Answerde, “Ywis, my dere herte trewe
Thus were al lost, ywis, min herte dere
“And trusteth this, that certes, herte swete
Sin to be trewe I have yow plight my trouthe.
I shal so doon, so trewe I have yow founde
That hem hath holpen, whan that they were seke.
The chambres and the stables weren wide
His hors were goode, but he was nat gay.
Al ful of fresshe floures, white and rede.
Short was his gown, with sleves longe and wide.
Harneised wel, and sharpe as point of spere;
For unto a poure ordre for to yive
For many a man so harde is of his herte
To make his English swete upon his tonge;
He semed swich, his wordes weren so wise.
For he was Epicurus owne sone
Poinaunt and sharpe, and redy al his gere.
Ful fresh and newe hir gere apiked was;
Hir frendshipe nas nat newe to biginne.
Ful streite yteid, and shoos ful moiste and newe.
And was a povre Parson of a toun;
A trewe swinkere and a good was he
For Cristes sake, for every povre wight
His nose-thirles blake were and wide.
For to be wise in byinge of vitaille.
Ful longe were his legges, and ful lene
A povre person dwelling upon lond
Our counseil was nat longe for to seche;
And therto he was sleigh° and ful privee,°
And he himself as swete as is the rote°
His Almageste° and bookes grete and smale
And tho° were bent, and blake as any sloo.°
Hir mouth was swete as bragot° or the meeth,°
As clerkes ben ful subtile and ful queinte;°
That but° ye waite wel° and been privee,°
And strouted° as a fanne large and brode;
She was so propre° and swete and likerous.°
